It's a great class that provides a comprehensive review of FDA laws with case studies. Prof Kesselheim is knowledgeable and experienced with FDA laws, which gave me insights into the class! He also communicated with students through daily FDA related news often and kept us in check.
Great class, incredible lectures and guest speakers, all around very happy with the course.
This is a very comprehensive introduction course for someone wants to learn about FDA Law and Policy. The  materials covered a broad collection of topics  and with good supporting cases.
Fantastic course that covers a lot of very important material.

It's a lecture course at the law school. As an mph student, I guess I was expecting more of an interactive learning experience with more discussions, especially when they limited the number of mph students according to how many law students took the course. There were discussion points, but it was more of a guess-the-answer type and some byo current events. There was so much hype about it at the beginning of the semester, but all in all it's quite a normal lecture about the history of the FDA. It's cross listed as a ysph course, but you feel like you decided to purposefully take a Law-school-only course. 
The greatest strength was that the professor was really an expert.

+ This really shouldn't be cross-listed as a YSPH course. if it is cross-listed in ysph, the class should be more welcoming of ysph students and their backgrounds. During the extra classes we have to take, maybe there should be a quick basics of what-1Ls-learn overview. Securities, trade secrets, how to effectively read a case, etc. I do not think this class should be taken in complete absence of other basic law classes. Or at least have a TF.

This course is an excellent introduction to FDA law and policy. The lectures are extremely informative. The students who take the course are able to discuss readings and current issues at a high level so the discussions typically brought out interesting points. The only weakness might be the lack of interactive work with other students. We had one "extra class" that was optional, but the group exercises in decision-making during this session were very stimulating.

This course introduces students to the most important food and drug law concepts.  I would make no changes.  Professor Kesselheim has accomplished a near miracle with the comprehensiveness and breadth of this course, without making it feel like an oppressive amount of work.
Great course for those interested in pharma/ FDA law

strengths: donuts, good overview of history leading to the current FDA framework, fast-paced, interesting topics covered in the extra classes
weaknesses: we're graded on participation but sometimes lectures can be so jam-packed that there's not much room for class discussion

Strengths: Excellent instructor; Engaging discussions; A nice mix of primary and secondary readings; Challenging final project
Weaknesses: Class only meets 8 times, plus bonus sessions for YSPH students; I think more writing assignments throughout the semester would have been helpful, though given the class size may require a TF.
He's an amazing professor!

It is a true pleasure to learn from and speak with Dr. Kesselheim. He is brilliant and very talented at leading a course on and discussing FDA law. My only feedback would be to minimize the details of some regulatory lectures and focus more on discussion instead.
Professor Kesselheim gave thoughtful feedback and was always available to students, despite living in Boston.

Prof. Kesselheim has a very energetic teaching style and always brought us Donuts (*not as a bribery so that we will rate him 5 star). He is very logical about the flow of teaching materials and all the materials are specifically selected.
Great lecturer. Very experienced in his profession and knows the subject matter incredibly well. He is also extremely responsive to student emails.
A good and sweet professor who brought us snacks every week despite coming from Boston each time.
Dr. Kesselheim is truly expert in this field. He is also wonderfully supportive and giving of his time. One of the best!

Yale is lucky to have him.  Hes a true expert but also one of the best teachers I have ever had at any level.  Hes funny in an endearing way.  Hes THE expert.  No one else knows how much Aaron Kesselheim knows about FDA law.  Hes extremely gifted at balancing lectures with the Socratic method.
Professor Kesselheim is incredibly knowledgable and this is a great opportunity to learn from someone of his caliber!

strengths: friendly, gives prompt feedback, engaging speaker
weaknesses: sometimes runs out of time and has to cover concepts in the next class
Excellent Professor, who creates a great learning environment for questions and discussion.
Professor Kesselheim is approachable, informative and engaging. A fantastic professor, and one everyone should take a class with if possible.
It is a great class if you are interested in FDA laws. It is in general an overview and comprehensive review of FDA responsibility and specific regulations. But it is not a techinical class
Incredible class - definitely take
A very good regulatory introduction course for anyone wants to enter healthcare industry.
Great course if you are interested in healthcare.
If you're interested in FDA Law, sure take it. But if you're not going to go into health law, taking Regulatory Affairs gives you enough of the realities of FDA.
If you are interested in getting a solid foothold in FDA history, law, and policy, you cannot go wrong with this course.
Absolute must if you want to learn about FDA law.  There is no teacher more talented in both knowledge and pedagogy than Aaron Kesselheim when it comes to FDA law.
Take it!

I liked this course a lot and would recommend it to another student! It was well-structured, and legal developments are covered chronologically, so even if you're not intimately acquainted with the US judicial/legal system, you'll be able to catch on easily enough. I particularly like the discussions on controversial cases, and hearing about recent FDA news in the class newsletter.
Highly recommended.
This course does not cover the Food or (really) the tobacco aspects of the FDA. If you are interested in drug regulation however, this is a must.
